text: A “Tuscan"-style tract house in a remote, snow-covered fi The house looks very out of place, probably because this isn’t Tuscany. A deer grazes nearby. There’s a plastic “life-size” NATIVITY SCENE in the yard. BABY JESUS is discreetly tethered to the manger with a bi lock. Theft prevention.

head_text.subj: A POOR-QUALITY VIDEO TAKEN AT A TALENT SHOW.

text: LAMB MANNERHEIM, 17, grips a microphone and paces the sta Lamb is pretty, but in an extremely modest, wholesome way Her clothes are dated, and she wears her long hair in an fashioned style. Think Walmart meets Little House on the Prairie. A homemade American Idol-inspired banner on the stage rea “Christ is OUR Idol! Youth Talent Night 2007.” Lamb takes this performance very seriously, even if it’s for friends and family. She holds the mic like a pro, fan her fingers and using moves she’s learned from TV. She sm and begins to sing in an unsteady, nervous voice. The song is “Place in This World,” a Christian anthem by Michael W. Smith.

The wind is moving But I am standing still A life of pages Waiting to be filled INT. MANNERHEIM HOUSE (LAMB’S BEDROOM) - MORNING We pan past a wall of family photos and mass-produced Christian art. A sticker that says “Real Women Eat Meat.” MONTANA BIBLE COLLEGE pennant. A cross. Lamb, now 21, is lying in bed. Faintly, as if underwater, hear the singing performance playing in another room.
A heart that's hopeful A head that's full of dreams (MORE )
Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 2.

But this becoming Is harder than it seems Lamb rolls over stiffly. We see her arms, covered with FL TONED COMPRESSION GARMENTS-- they’re like Ace bandages crossed with fingerless gloves. Lamb sits up, slowly and with effort. She’s a pretty youn woman. But her shoulders and neck are marred by PINK SCAR TISSUE. The scars could be covered with the right clothin but right now, every flaw is exposed. She winces in pain. Every day begins with pain.
ow. We INTERCUT with the video, which we can now deduce is playing in another room of the house.

I'm looking for a reason Roamin' through the night to find My place in this world My place in this world Lamb groans, stiffly swinging her legs out of bed. She wiggles her toes and reaches for a prescription PILL BOTT close at hand. Lamb dry-swallows four Vicodin pills in rapid succession- she’s a pro at this. We see that there’s a cup of HOT CHOCOLATE waiting for he the bed table. A CANDY CANE and some MINI-MARSHMALLOWS dissolve in the cocoa. Lamb moves the cup, revealing that napkin/coaster bears a handwritten message: “You R Still Pretty!!! XOxO Mom." Lamb wrinkles her nose at the cocoa.
Ugh. Lamb exits the room and follows the sound of the talent s video to its source.

The living room is bedecked with religious Christmas item  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 3. MELANIE and DOUG MANNERHEIM, Lamb’s surprisingly young parents, are watching the talent show video on a gigantic plasma TV. MELANIE is an attractive woman with flowing curls and a sparkling bejeweled cross necklace. DOUG has spiky hair and a fitted button-down shirt with E Hardy-esque embroidery on it. As they watch the video, Melanie provides rapid-fire commentary:
This part I thought she did so well. You know that thing she does where she kind of takes off and makes it her own? That’s called a “run.” Doug has watched this many times before.
I know.
Lamb could have gotten a talent agent. I should have taken her to that open call in Missoula.
That was a a long time ago. Lamb's annoyed voice interrupts.

Mom, you’re watching this again? Lamb has appeared in the living room entry, looking disheveled and vulnerable with her scars and compression garments on rare display. Melanie reacts as though she’s been caught watching porn.
(startled) Oh! Lamb. You’re up early. Doug, where’s the clicker? She roots around for the remote control. Finds a couple o them in the couch. Flings them aside.
The small clicker...
‘Morning, Lamb.

Do you want your robe? The Mannerheim household is a modest one, and Melanie isn comfortable looking at Lamb uncovered. She tries to turn the tape, but only succeeds in TURNING UP THE VOLUME. Lam shouts over the song.
I asked you not to watch this anymore. I even hid the tape in Dad’s gun safe. Doug looks at Melanie. She sighs.

We all know the combination is the dog's birthday. On the TV: a young, stunning Lamb sings: My place in this world. My place in this world. Lamb stares numbly at her former self on the giant screen as Doug turns down the volume. MELANIE (CONT’D) Let’s get your robe. You must be freezing.
I’m a burn victim. I’m always freezing. Read the pamphlets again. An awkward silence.
Hey, did you see Mom made you a Candy Cane Cocoa?
I even put some midget marshmallows in there. (to Doug) Is it okay to say “midget” if it’s about a confection?
I'd say little. Mini. Lamb interrupts angrily. She gestures to the TV, where he younger self still sings.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 5.
Why the-- why the hell are you doing this to me? Both parents pause, surprised by her language. Lamb has n uttered the word “hell” in her life. (At least not in thi context.)
Lamb!
This is bull. Now Doug and Melanie are shocked.
That’s enough cursing.
(to Doug) Maybe she didn’t take her medication yet. She has so much pain in the morning.
I took it, Mom. I took four.
You mean you took one...
Times four.
Lamb, you’re supposed to be tapering off the pills.

Well, Mom, you’re supposed to be “tapering off” the scrapbooks and photo albums and talent show videos from back when I didn’t look like Frankenstein. Now turn it off. (hesitating) Damn it! Melanie shuts off the TV and stares at her daughter. Curs is one thing. Taking the Lord’s name in vain is another entirely.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 6.
Lamb Grace Mannerheim. Did you just say the worst curse in my Tuscan mini-mansion?
Frankenstein was the doctor, not the monster. You’re an English major, honey. You should know that.
I was an English major.
You're still technically enrolled.
You might say I’m burned out on college, Dad. Get it? Ha ha.
You were doing so good. What’s gotten into you lately?
(to Melanie) Could be the Devil.
(whispering) Duh. Obviously. Lamb gives up, her shoulders sagging in defeat.
I’m sorry. I’m really sorry. I’m just not feeling well today. Got my monthly bill.
What bill? Lamb trudges off back toward her room.
I’m going to go practice my guest sermon, okay?

Let me know when you’re ready for hair and makeup. Melanie and Doug exchange glances as she leaves. This isn the Lamb they know.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 7. INT. LAMB'S ROOM —- MORNING Lamb sits on her bed. She wears a modest dress, a flowere headband and lace tights. Her hair is pulled up into one those pouf/braid combos commonly seen on fundamentalist Christian women. Melanie has a large professional tacklebox filled with makeup. She uses a puff to apply some type of cover-up po to Lamb’s scars.

This is from our new line. It’s all- natural minerals from the earth. It covers everything. You know Shana Qualley’s mom? She has a lot of redness from, well, from drinking. I use this on her and she looks a lot better. Not good-- that would take a miracle-- but better. Lamb says nothing.
I really don’t like to talk about people. (finishing) There. You look radiant. Lamb looks at her neck and collarbones in the mirror. It’ not an improvement. We still see the scars.
Dr. Cha says I’m not supposed to put anything on there.
Lamb, it’s 100% natural. One of our representatives puts this on her four-year-old every day.
Why? Melanie is putting away her makeup tools. She closes the tackle box.
Do you feel ready to give your guest sermon?
Mm-hm  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 8.
If you get nervous, just imagine Pastor Rick in his underwear.
(uncomfortable) That won’t be necessary.
Let me just hear the beginning. Lamb sighs, dutiful.
“My beloved family in worship. I stand here today as miraculous evidence of God’s healing grace...” Do I have to practice right now?
No. Just remember: God’s counting on you. You can make a difference with what you say today. It’s like I always say, you can affect change in a small way and it makes a big ripple. Like a--
(interrupting) Like a toot in the bathtub. I know.
That’s right. She kisses Lamb’s “pouf.”

The Mannerheim’s car pulls up to a GIANT MEGA-CHURCH COMP The vast parking lot is filling up with worshippers. The church's giant marquee-type sign reads: “WHY ‘TWEET’ SATAN WHEN YOU CAN ‘FOLLOW’ CHRIST?”
The Mannerheim’s are bundled up in parkas and scarves. Melanie rolls down the window and peeks out at the overflowing parking lot.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy)
Will you look at this clusterhug? I love seeing this many people come together in His name, don’t you?
I think some of them just come for the smoothies. We see that one of the many entrances to the church superstructure says “GOD'S BOUNTY SMOOTHIES & COFFEE.”
We're lucky to belong to a church with amenities. The Catholics don’t have a juice bar.
The Catholics get to drink the actual blood of Christ.
They think that, don’t they? Aren’t our differences interesting? I'1l pray for them. Doug, park over by the gift shop. I want to pick up a new journal after church. (to Lamb) I’ve been writing.
Good for you, Mom.
I'm writing a little story about an old man and an old woman and their whole epic love story going back decades.
Sounds like The Notebook.
Um, it’s totally unlike The Notebook. I wouldn’t copy my own favorite book that I’ve read 100 times, would I? (then) Doug, there’s one.
A VAN from an assisted living home pulls into Melanie's chosen parking spot.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 10. MELANIE (CONT’D) (annoyed) God BLESS it.
A loud CHRISTIAN HIP-HOP BAND plays. Two RAPPERS-- a whit guy and an Asian girl-- bust some rhymes.
Jesus, you're my savior. You made me like Xavier. Roberts. Your creation. You rule the nation!

I love Jesus like William love Kate. Jesus, you're my prince, let's set the date. Melanie, Doug and Lamb take their seats in the front row the massive auditorium. On the walls of the church, we see a few large POSTERS wi photo of a smiling Lamb. She wears a black dress with pea her neck and arms are creamy and scar-free. The posters say: LAMB MANNERHEIM SHARES HER INSPIRATIONAL STORY OF SURVIVAL. SUNDAY, DECEMBER 17, 10:00 SERVICE.
The posters came out nice. I need one of those for my brag wall.
Is that the picture you sent them? Why did you send them an old photo?

It’s the nicest photo we have of you. That reminds me, we need to go to the portrait studio as a family. We could wear matching outfits and jump in the air! (off Lamb’s dour look) Or we could sit nicely. Lamb is fixated on the poster.
I don’t look like that anymore. I looked like a Barbie. (MORE )
Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 11.
Now I look like a Barbie that got tortured with a lighter.
First of all, you were never any kind of Barbie. You’re obviously a Skipper. She discreetly indicates Lamb’s small chest.
Mom!

Honey, if I could crank your arm and make them grow, I would. Secondly, self-pity is unbecoming. You're getting better every day. People don’t even look anymore. We see a MOM and DAD trying in vain to keep their KIDS fr staring at Lamb. A LITTLE GIRL, who’s about 2, starts to point and cry loudly. MELANIE (CONT’D) That’s a tough age. They take their seats. As Melanie and Doug socialize with people seated around them, Lamb begins to NOD OFF.
Lamb WAKES UP, a bit dazed. PASTOR RICK, the young, hands dynamic leader of the congregation, is introducing her.

...-And now, we have a very inspiring young lady who’s agreed to talk to all of you today. Lamb Mannerheim has been a member of our church family, since, well, since I was a kid! She’s been a valued youth evangelist, the valedictorian of her home school collective and a favorite performer in our music ministry. When we think of well- formed, righteous, feminine role models, we think about girls like Lamb. (clearing his throat) (MORE )
Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 12.

As you all know, Lamb survived a tragic accident while she was away at Montana Bible College two years ago. As a community, we felt her pain and loss. But now, she’s miraculously back on her feet to share a courageous Christmas tale of faith and healing. Brothers and sisters...Lamb Mannerheim. Lamb stands up and makes her way to the podium. She gets STANDING OVATION from the appreciative crowd. We can see Pastor Rick CHECK HER OUT briefly (but inappropriately) as she takes the stage.

Thanks Pastor Rich. Good morning, everyone. I know you’re all expecting me to deliver testimony about the accident and how, through the grace of God, I recovered. But really, you were hoping to hear gory details about the crash. Like how I could smell myself burning, but I couldn’t feel it. On Melanie: her face falls. This wasn’t what they practic But Lamb remains calm, smiling, even serene.

Isn't that funny? I was in the parking lot of a Kroger, on fire, and as I laid there, all I could think about was my shoes. That they looked strange. “I don’t remember wearing clogs today. Oh. I didn’t. They’re regular shoes, but they’re melting. And, come to think of it, so am I.” The crowd begins to murmur. Lamb continues brightly.

Well, the accident was bad. But the surgeries-- those were even worse. Did you know they can take skin from your butt and put it on your back? And where does that leave your butt? (chuckling) I guess thongs are out of the question now! Sorry Pastor Rick.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 13. Now everyone is really uncomfortable.

But enough of that. What I’m really here to say today is that the horrible, unspeakable pain I endured didn’t strengthen my faith in the slightest. In fact, I’ve become an athiest. I’m here to share my new wisdom with you. Everyone, there is no God. Pastor Rick appears at her side, but she slaps him away.

Don’t touch me. My skin grafts are very fragile. I could bleed all over our nice new alter carpeting and then you’d have to take up another collection! (to congregation) Another collection. You already tithe most of your income to this place. How’s that working out for you? Do the skate park and the putting green make you feel more righteous?
Lamb, stop! Get down from there!

I’m not done yet, Mom. Almost. Okay, so I don’t believe in God. Here’s what I do believe: I believe in science. I believe in the doctors who were there when I woke up. I believe in opiates and morphine, which work whether you have faith in them or not. I’m willing to believe that the universe was created in an explosion, and that fish-creatures crawled out of the mud and evolved into human beings. And, in our next presidential election... (pause) I may vote for Obama. That does it. Chaos breaks out in the auditorium.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 14.

Before I’m forcibly removed from the stage, I want to say that I’m leaving Billings for a while. I’ve spent my entire life abstaining from earthly vices and drinking the smoothie of ignorance concocted by this very church. Tomorrow, I’m getting on a plane to Las Vegas, Nevada, where I plan to gamble, drink alcohol, and frolic with homosexuals-— Melanie seizes control of the podium. Feedback squawks as Melanie grabs the mic and interrupts in a shaky voice.
I'm very sorry, everyone. My daughter is still recovering.
(sarcastic) What? Mother, I’m radiant! Melanie is too close to the mic. Her voice booms in an unintentionally hilarious way.
Please pray for us.
Or don’t. The last time you prayed for me I wound up looking like this. Wah-wah!
Let’s get you out of here. She reaches for Lamb, who lunges back toward the mic, pul her cardigan aside to reveal her shoulders. She shouts cheerfully into the mic.
My shoulders look like turkey bacon! God who? As Melanie takes Lamb’s elbow and hustles her away from t podium, she accidentally hurts her daughter's skin.
ow. She collapses and grabs her elbow.  15.

Oh no! Baby, are you okay? The sound drops out. Lamb shouts a VERY BAD WORD. The forbidden curse echoes off the walls of the enormous church. A fitting climax to Lamb’s public rejection of Go Doug takes a long, uncomfortable sip from his “God’s Boun smoothie.

Lamb is sitting on the crowded Vegas-bound PLANE. She wea modest dress and looks bewildered and overwhelmed. A TEENAGE GUY, 17, stashes his stuff in the overhead compartment and climbs into the seat next to hers. He stares at the fingerless COMPRESSION GARMENTS on her a and hands as if they’re some cool accessory.
Where’d you get those gloves? Lamb can barely hide her annoyance.
The Mayo Clinic. (then) They're compression garments. Like big Band-Aids.
Oh. Do you cut?
Do I what?
Like, are you a cutter? Do you cut yourself on purpose, like with a razor blade or a knife?
No. The guy pulls up his arm to reveal a ladder of 4 or 5 sma pathetic red slashes. Scratches, barely.
Check it.  Lamb is offended by these self-inflicted wounds.
You should be ashamed of that.
Why?
Because it’s disrespectful. That’s your arm. You are the earthly custodian of that arm and you choose to treat it like a whittling block?
A what?
A block of wood that one whittles.
It’s not my fault. My therapist says I have a textbook “Type D” personality.
"Type D"?
Depressed. It means you pretty much want to kill yourself all the time. Lamb considers this.

When I feel “depressed”, I go fora bike ride in the sunshine or I play my flute or I read Scripture (catching herself) -- well, I don’t read Scripture since I renounced God, but the other two. Anyway, I would never cut my body. That seems counterintuitive if you’re trying to be of good cheer. The guy stares at her.
Sunshine and the flute? Are you from that family on TV that has like 20 kids and is in a cult? 16.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 17.
I don’t watch TV. (quietly) Also, it’s not a cult. They’re just Baptists. A pause. The guy drums his fingers anxiously on the armre
I hate takeoff. I get so jumpy on planes.
There’s pretty much zero chance this plane will go down.
I know there’s all those statistics, like, safer than a car and stuff but...
No. Factually speaking, the odds of this plane crashing are much lower than you realize. Like one in approximately ten trillion, since I’m on here.
(scoffing) What, because you’re magic or something?
No. Because it never happens to anyone twice. The guy, realizing, stares at Lamb in awe.
Type D. (shaking her head) D for Dummy. My goodness. She takes a brand new copy of The Audacity of Hope by Bar Obama out of her bag, cracks the spine, and begins readin

The teenage guy sleeps. Lamb is wide awake, bored with he book. She gazes out the window.  18. She turns to the personal IN-FLIGHT ENTERTAINMENT SCREEN the seatback in front of her. She presses “Movies.” Lots of options come up. Lamb scrolls past the family- friendly categories, determined to corrupt herself. She chooses a category called “Exclusive! Vegas-Inspired Movi to Get You in the Mood!” We see a selection of famous Las Vegas moves: The Hangove What Happens in Vegas. Leaving Las Vegas and then... Showgirls. If it’s possible for a person to blush at the sight of a movie title, Lamb does. The movie is aptly described as “The Cult Classic Erotic Thriller!” Lamb glances at her seatmate. Still sleeping. The aisle s is occupied by a senior citizen doing Sudoku. Tentatively, Lamb presses “Play” on Showgirls. She makes no one is looking and settles in.

Lamb is watching the infamous pool sex scene. Her brow is furrowed, as if she’s watching an interesting ritual from some foreign civilization. The teenage guy stirs. Lamb immediately leans forward and tries to turn off the movie.

(dazed) Hm? (seeing) Whoa! All right! Lamb is wildly pressing the “home” icon on the touchscree It’s stuck on Showgirls, frozen in the land of violent po sex. TEENAGE GUY (CONT’D) What is this? Species? Lamb is mortified, but holds her head high.
Showgirls.
I would not have thought you would choose this particular film.  19.
Well, I did. (primly) I love erotic thrillers. The guy cranes his neck to check out the screen
Me too. Lamb looks away, but her eyes wander back to the screen.
Lamb moves through the airport, past the ding-ding-ding o slot machines and hordes of tourists. The whole place is decorated for Christmas and the mood is both festive and profane.

Lamb stands at the baggage claim and waits for her suitca She carries her flute in a black case. Three STRIPPERS from the same flight wait just behind her the crowd. They wear sweatsuits in contrasting pastels. STRIPPER #1 is a Latina beauty with hair down to her wais and 0% body fat. She stamps her feet dramatically.
I need a smoke so bad. STRIPPER #2 is a tan, corn-fed blonde.
You're making it worse by talking about it.
Ladies, I got that feeling like I’m gonna bank this weekend. I’m gonna make six Gs.
Nobody makes six Gs anymore. Not even feature girls.
I know the economy sucks, but this bubble don’t break.  20. She does a few booty-pops. The girls giggle. STRIPPER #3 is a tough, short girl.

If I even make one G, I’‘ll be happy. We keep coming out here for the weekends, but truth is, Vegas is as broke as Montana. (to Lamb) Hey, can you grab that big Louie for me? A LOUIS VUITTON suitcase is making its way around the carousel. It’s positioned in such a way that Lamb can rea it but the stripper can’t. Lamb isn’t sure what a “Louie” but she guesses.
This one? She grabs the bag with difficulty and swings it over to i owner. The strippers see the scars on Lamb’s arm as she reaches forward.
Girl, what happened to you? Stripper #1 is embarrassed by her friend’s rudeness.
Lexus!
Looks like someone said they was gonna cut a bitch and actually did it. Damn. (by way of apology) You still cute, though.
Yeah. She’s cute. She could probably get a day shift at the Lumberyard.
The Lumberyard?
You know the Lumberyard in Helena? We work there. (then, aggressive) Yeah, I said it. There’s no shame in the game.  21.
Why would you be ashamed of that? Christ was a carpenter. The girls exchange glances and burst into peals of laught It’s not “mean girl” laughter, per se, but genuine surpri at Lamb’s dorkiness.
We're not carpenters. The Lumberyard is a gentlemen's club.
Oh. Ah. You’d think I would have gotten that, since I just watched Showgirls on the plane. (whispering) I know all about what you do. An awkward beat.

Right. You got it all figured out. The girls shake their heads as Lamb reaches onto the bagg carousel and takes her childish pink suitcase. We see pee letters printed on the suitcase: GOING TO GRANDMA’S. Lamb extends the handle and walks away, rolling it behind with her head held high. The strippers watch, amused.
Lamb approaches the taxi stand, where a jaded ATTENDANT f down cars. Clutching her printed itinerary, she takes a d breath.
One taxi, please.
Uh-huh. Where you headed?
Um, the Planet Hollywood Resort?
Play-Ho. Got it.
Planet Hollywood.  22. The attendant tosses her pink suitcase carelessly into th trunk of a waiting cab. It lands with a THUNK as Lamb mee protests.
Hey, I have dishes in there. The man stares at her.
Why'd you bring dishes to Las Vegas? Lamb climbs into the back seat of the cab. She goes to bu up and discovers only a lap belt.
(to driver) Sir? Is there a shoulder belt?
(thickly accented) What, you want a baby seat too? Goo goo. The attendant slams the door shut and the cab squeals awa
Lamb admires the spectacular lights of the Strip from the back of the cab. Remembering Showgirls, she decides to as about a certain Vegas landmark.
Excuse me, sir. Where is the Stardust? The driver's accent and ethnic background are impossible place.
Eh?
The Stardust Hotel. Where they have the Goddess musical performance?
Stardust? That was, eh, bombed a few years ago. Blown up inside with dynamite. Big boom. Lamb has been raised to be very wary of terrorism.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 23.
Oh, no. (whispering) Was it Muslims?

Muslims? No, man! The guy who owned it blew it up with purpose so he could build a new hotel. What do you think I know about some terrorists? (then) Ah, I hate this Trop light. They're stopped at the intersection of Las Vegas Boulevar and Tropicana. It’s gridlock on every side.
Trop light?

Yeah, man. Tropicana. Longest light in town. The cab slows to a stop. Lamb looks out the window at the York, New York roller coaster and the Excalibur’s fake ca turrets illuminated overhead. She’s enchanted by the sigh
Kind of looks like Disney World.
(sarcastic) Disney World. Ha. That place? You ever been to Disney World?
No. I wasn’t allowed to, because the Disney Corporation supports the homosexual agenda.

Last night, in this cab, I have two gay guys getting married. I got no problem with it. As long as they keep their penis inside the blue jeans. I said, if I see some gay, I see some Doogie Howser bullshit, you're out! Here we are. He pulls over to the curb quickly, sending Lamb flying.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 24.
The driver takes Lamb’s pink suitcase out of the trunk. L nervously peels off a few bills from a conspicuously larg WAD OF CASH.
Here.
Thanks. Hey, you know how you said you weren’t allowed to go to Disney World?
Yes?
Was the Disney Channel also forbidden?
Yes, sir. Emphatically so.
Even The Wizards of Waverley Place?
Satanists. Lamb turns and walks toward the hotel with her suitcase a her flute. The driver looks down with surprise at the LARGE WAD OF M she’s handed him.
You sure?

Lamb walks into the hotel. She scans the room nervously. early in the evening. TOURISTS play craps and blackjack a wander around with drinks. The scene is relatively tame a even a little hokey. Lamb seems relieved.
Huh. It’s kinda like Branson. An OLD WOMAN pulls the lever on a cheesy branded slot machine. The machine discharges a few quarters.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 25.
No problem. She steps forward bravely.

Lamb, checked in, tucks her room key into her pocket. She about to walk to the elevator, but she pauses and goes in the hotel’s gift shop. Lamb takes a tacky, sparkly T-shirt off one of the racks. says “I (HEART) LAS VEGAS,” only instead of a heart, ther - nonsensically-- a pair of dice.
(whispering) “I Dice Las Vegas.” It doesn't look like anything Lamb would normally wear. B nothing about this night is normal.

Lamb, now holding a SHOPPING BAG, waits for an elevator t take her up to her room. From where she stands, we can already hear some raucous shouting coming up the elevator shaft. The elevator doors open, revealing about 5 WET FRAT BOYS coming up from the pool area. They’re drunk and in variou states of undress. Think damp towels, tribal tattoos, steroidal acne and loud, booming voices.
I swear, I only had a half a pill, but I’m rolling so hard.
Dude, I’m flying. We should call those sluts from Tao and get an eight ball for tonight.
Phenomenal, bro!
Phenomenal.
Hey.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 26. The shouting and laughing stops abruptly when they notice Lamb standing there. Silence. Lamb primly steps into the elevator.

The frat boys are trying to hold it together, but they’re making crazy expressions at each other and (barely) suppressing laughter. They don’t know how to respond to a pretty girl who’s been desexualized by injury. Finally, o of the guys talks.
Hi.
Hello. One of the guys begins to crowd her in a creepy way. He strokes her ponytail. One of them whispers
Uh, where are you from? The other guys snicker. This is the equivalent of the hig school quarterback hitting on an ugly girl to make his friends laugh.
(under his breath) Chernobyl. Huh huh.
I’m from D.C.
Oh yeah?
Yes. I’m a federal agent. Drug enforcement.
Oh really?

I just orchestrated a huge meth lab sting in Iowa. The place blew sky high. Messed me up pretty bad, as you can see. But I’m back in action. Vegas is my new beat. Lamb's voice is shaking, but she sticks to her story.  27.
Wow.

I'm looking forward to making some arrests. The people here aren’t very discreet, so it should be easy! Plus, I’m a super-smeller. You know drug-sniffing dogs? I'ma drug-sniffing human. I’m accurate up to four yards, that’s how I got into the DEA. I beat out a golden retriever in tests.
(to his friend) Hey, let’s get off here, man.
Yeah, yeah. We passed our floor. They begin stabbing buttons in a panic. The doors open on mezzanine level.

This isn’t your level is it? This looks like a convention of Chicano attorneys. An easel-style SIGN welcomes people to the NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF CHICANO ATTORNEYS. Nevertheless, the frat guys all scurry off the elevator, failing to blend in with the crowd. Lamb exhales as the doors close. She closes her eyes. The encounter scared her more than she let on.
Lamb takes out her key card. We see a group of cute, happ SOMETHING GIRLS headed out for a night on the town. They down the hall toward the elevator, holding hands.
Wait, Zoe, this is your first time seeing Cirque? You're so gonna cry.
Oh my God, I know.  28.
Liz, those shoes are phenomenal. So phenomonal.
Phenomenal! Wistfully, Lamb watches them as they pass. She tries out word everyone her age is (over)using.
Phenomenal. Phenomenal. She slides her key into the door. The light turns green.

Oh. Yeah, you always see these on the Strip. Kind of grim, I guess.
I can’t stop thinking about her. I wish I could find her. She must be so scared, don’t you think?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 58.
Ah, this isn’t even a real girl. These places use fake, misleading pictures. (then) I hear.
The picture might be fake, and the name might be fake, but if you dial this number, a real human being shows up. William scans the flier.
She does in-call as well. That means you can also come to her...
(interrupting) I’m worried about her. William, jaded, can’t believe how idealistic this girl is
You can’t just go around saving people. Trying to do that here is like that arcade game, you know, with the little mallet? You put one devil down, another one’s just gonna pop up.

My religion (catching herself) Well, I’m an atheist now, but my former religion says if you can save one soul, you can save the world. Lamb is rummaging in her purse. She takes out her VICODIN BOTTLE and opens it. She shakes out three pills. Shakes again. NOTHING LEFT.
Oh no. Oh gosh.
What is it? Lamb is panicking.  59.
Some of my pills are missing. I need these.
No worries. You probably have, like, unlimited refills right?
Somebody stole from me. They stole medication from a burn survivor. (then) Do you think Loray would take it? William’s guilt is suddenly compounded.
No. Loray wouldn’t do that.
I don’t know her.

Oh. No. She’s so good, Lamb. She’s a deeply good person. She loves the Beach Boys. (serious) I’ve worked with her for four years; she’s like my sister. She’s my pit wife. Please don’t even think for a second it was Loray. You have enough for now, right? There’s a bunch of 24-hour pharmacies right around here. I'll drive you.
Okay. The mood has changed. Lamb swallows one of her remaining Vicodins as William looks around for something, anything, cheer her up. He glances at the big TV.
Hey, you wanna see if there’s a silly movie on or something?
(dejected) Sure.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 60.
Loray is grinding with a HEAVILY BEARDED GUY. She takes a swig of beer and tries unsuccessfully to make out with hi through his mass of facial hair.
I can’t find your mouth.

William takes a remote from behind the bar and turns on t big TV. He flips through the channels and finds... The classic 1960s special, Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer Lamb reacts like a delighted child.
Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer! I remember this. William watches with her, equally pleased. The light flic on their faces.
Of course. Total classic. Even I’ve seen this and my childhood was a blur of beatings and evictions.

I watched this like, every year when I was little. Then my parents realized it left the Christ out of Christmas, and that was the end of that. They watch for a moment. It’s the “Island of Misfit Toys” sequence, in which a haunting song is sung by imperfect t a polka-dotted elephant, a boat that doesn’t float, a tra with square wheels, and a lonely little rag doll (among others).
Oh, this part is so sad. These are the Misfit Toys. Nobody wants them because they’re defective.
(on TV) How'd you like to be a spotted elephant?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 61.
(onscreen) Or a boat that can't float? Lamb watches, her eyes shining. Then:
What’s wrong with the doll?
I don’t know. Nobody wants her.

Seriously, though, what’s her defect? I can see the train has square wheels. And the elephant has polka-dots. But that little doll looks completely normal. What’s she doing with those broken toys? We see the rag doll. She does look perfectly normal. (Thi one thing that has never made sense about the “Misfit Toy scene.)
We probably just can’t see what’s wrong with her.
You think it’s under her dress or something? Lamb is uncomfortable. Her voice is strained.
Yeah.
Or...maybe she’s perfect.
Nah.
Maybe she’s just in the wrong place. Loray emerges from the stairwell, interrupting them. She glances at the TV, drunk and dismissive.
What is this? Gumby?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 62. William and Lamb groan at Loray’s flippancy toward such a beloved show.
You don’t know what this is?
You guys need to come downstairs immediately. Some people are line dancing as a joke. William fakes jumping out of his seat. Then:
She needs to rest.
No, I’m fine now. Much better. They rise and head toward the stairwell. Loray continues babbling happily.
Hey William, you know that girl who always does the splits? She did it again. I'm like, bitch, we get it, you can put your whole vagina on the floor.
Okay.
I’m gonna fight her.
I think it’s time to switch to water. Loray takes a last glance at the TV and shakes her head a they descend. She loudly whispers to William.
You take a girl upstairs and you put on cartoons? You’re a mess.
Lamb, William and Loray walk down Fremont Street, eating DOGS from a busy food truck.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 63.
So is dirty street meat against your religion? Lamb is enjoying her hot dog immensely.
I think it could be my religion. CHARLIE, the CUTE GIRL BARTENDER suddenly rushes up to La still wearing her bar apron.
(breathless) Hey, thank you so much for that tip. Wow. I just wanted to say thanks before you take off. I really appreciate it.
No problem.
I can go to Burning Man now!
Great. Charlie, grinning, runs back into the bar. William realiz Lamb has left another massive tip, but shrugs it off as typical weirdness.
What was that all about?
I’m really not sure. A beat as they walk. William changes the subject, ticking Lamb's “crimes” off on his fingers.
So. You gambled, you drank, you danced with-- what did you call them, Sodomites?
Yes. I failed at all three tasks.
You watched a movie with Santa Claus. (redneck drawl) (MORE )
You're wearin’ anti-Amurrican clothing. He flicks at the fringe on Lamb's scarf.
What are you going to do next?
She needs to get turned out.
Hm? William shoots an annoyed look at Loray.
What? Don’t tell me “sins of the flesh” aren’t part of the agenda. It should be right there in your little Sanrio day planner: GET LAID. What else is there? At least you have to do something dirty.
(flustered) Okay. Well. Okay then. Let’s go...see...Goddess.
What's Goddess? Lamb is already blushing before she even describes it.

You know. The adults-only show? With the topless girls and the volcanoes? (sighing) You know, where Nomi performs in Showgirls? I know the Stardust isn’t there anymore, but maybe they moved the show to a different venue. Loray bursts out laughing.
Lamb, Showgirls is not real. Okay? It is not a documentary about Las Vegas. It is fiction. It came out of a horny Dutch man’s imagination.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 65.
I know! I just thought maybe Goddess was real. The character of Nomi, she makes such a big deal about being in it.
That’s perfectly understandable. I thought it was real myself.
(dying) William, you did not.
I did. I’ve looked for it. Checked every marquee.
All right, I’m an idiot. I'ma gullible idiot from the prairie. Where do we go next, then?
Back to Paradise, baby!
I thought we hated Paradise. I thought Paradise was processed cheese and dumb fountains, etcetera.
After hours is when the employees come out to play.
We know everyone, and everyone loves us. We can go wherever we want and our money is no good.

Um, I sort of need to find a pharmacy first. I take medication. For my pain. And somebody stole most of it. Loray glances at William. A COLD, DISAPPOINTED GLANCE, bu brief enough that Lamb doesn’t notice. Lamb turns to Lora
Do you think it could be one of your friends?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 66.
(sadly) Possibly.
I’ll take you, Lamb. Loray, come on. I don’t want you driving.
It’s fine. I’1l get a cab. (accusingly) You take her to the drug store, William. I’1l catch you later. She begins to walk away from them rather suddenly.
You sure?
Yeah, yeah, I need some breathing room. It’s like shawarma and liquor are having a UFC fight in my stomach. I’1ll see you guys on the Strip.
Okay. Lamb, high on life and being “cool”, flashes the peace si
Later! Peace out. Loray rolls her eyes.
William waits behind the wheel of his TOYOTA. Lamb runs o of the 24-hour Walgreens clutching a PAPER BAG from the pharmacy. She slides into the front seat cheerfully.
Phew. That wasn’t so hard. They had it right there in the computer. He watches her gobble down a couple of pills with a bit t much enthusiasm.
Good, great. (then) (MORE )
Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 67.
Hey, can I ask you a sensitive question?
Yes?
You know that prescription pain killers are extremely addictive, right?
I have very serious injuries.

No. I know. I know. I’m just saying that this is, sadly, my area of expertise. I happen to know that certain controlled substances, such as this one, can cause a dependency. Even when people don’t set out to abuse them. Lamb is crumpling the bag irritably.
I know all this. I spent six months in a hospital. I’m not some pill- abusing druggie criminal like the people you might know from “the joint.”
Lamb. She sees how serious he is.

It’s not something a person can always help. Even if they’re the most well-meaning, most responsible, nicest, loveliest person in the world and they’re named after a baby farm animal. Lamb looks away.
I know people who’ve been so hooked on that stuff that they’d do anything to get it. Gross things. Really bad things, not fake-fun-bad like what you’re doing here.  68.

Look, I know you guys think what I’m doing here is so funny, but you have no idea how serious it is to me. Being here tonight goes against every belief that’s been instilled in me. It’s like bending a bone backwards. I’m trying to smile and have fun and let go, but I feel like I’m going to snap.
If it makes you feel better, it’s not just you. Everyone who comes to Vegas is testing the tensile strength of their conscience.

Well, when does it get fun? I just want to have fun. How is this something people enjoy? Bars aren't fun. That bar smelled like the flu. And that dumb slot machine wasn’t fun. It took my money and just said “bar.” Great, I just paid ten dollars for a machine to tell me where I am. It’s not fun, William. I just want to do something that’s fun for me. William considers what might be fun for Lamb.
Hm.
The huge ROLLER COASTER looms over the Strip.

location: NEW YORK NEW YORK HOTEL, (ROLLER COASTER)

text: Lamb, William and Loray wait in line for the roller coast Loray’s arms are crossed and she’s pissed off. Lamb, howe looks THRILLED.
Now this is wild and crazy, you guys!
(humoring her) I know.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 69.
They didn’t have a roller coaster at Creation Land. I’ve never been on one. Aren’t you guys excited?
No.
Loray, I think you might be Type D.
What the hell is Type D?
You don’t know? It means depressed.
Maybe it’s just late on a Monday and I’m tired of being your magical negro.
What?
Oh, boy.

The “magical negro” is, uh, a narrative convention in which a black person uses their special black wisdom to help a dumb white person. We learned all about it in film school. Ghost, Green Mile, Bagger Vance. All magical negroes.
Except you're not wise or magical. Loray burps.
Yes I am! Lamb, don’t I say a lot of things that make you go, “Wow, Loray just told me! She’s so insightful.”
Yes.
That's extremely racist.  70.
I’m sorry.
(to Loray) Let’s face it. You’re no Bagger Vance.
Shut up.
Bagger Vance is immortal. He doesn’t age.
No, that’s just what Will Smith looks like.
No, the character didn’t age.

What was the right answer? What was I supposed to say. William tries to put a friendly arm around Loray, but she shrugs him off, annoyed. Now we can see she’s REALLY MAD, not about the Bagger Vance thing.
William, Lamb and Loray stand behind the automated airgat as the COASTER TRAIN arrives in the station.
Look, Lamb. There’s a spot open at the front. Take it. Lamb hesitates, peering at the front car.
But then I have to sit next to a strange man in a cowboy outfit.
This is your first ride. You gotta have the front so you can feel the bugs hit your teeth. Lamb looks again at her fellow passenger.  71.
The cowboy outfit has no...behind part.

Aw. Baby’s first assless chaps. Don’t worry. You don’t have to talk to him. Git. Lamb boldly jogs to the front of the coaster train. The airgates open. Loray is stuck riding with William. She lo away as they climb into the train and pull down the restraints.
Why are you mad at me?
You know why. The roller coaster lurches out of the station.
Don’t be like this.

It’s bad enough that you stole pain relief from a girl who’s held together with bandages and chewing gum. But it’s even worse that you're up her ass all night. The whole “white knight” routine you do. Helping her up that dark stairwell. Bringing her here-- you know we’re never caught dead doing this tacky shit! And you’re flirting with her. Making her feel pretty. It’s cruel.
She is pretty.
Obviously, yes, but she’s pretty like the Playboy Mansion. Looks like a dream, but you don’t want to pull up the carpet. The coaster ascends the lift hill.
Why are you here?  72.
(defensive) I don’t know, I felt like it tonight. My sponsor says I can’t stay in forever and I thought it was time.
Time. I bet it’s time. You’re here because you found a blonde virgin with a purse full of dope.
Lor, I have not broken any promises. I’ve been staying out of trouble.
“Trouble” is up there next to the naked cowboy, and you’re acting like you'd rather get in it.
I know this is hard to believe, coming from me. But I would never take advantage of her.
Ha. Yes, it is hard to believe coming from you. The man they call “William the Conqueror.” “Fill’em Will’em.” “Bill the Butcher”...
Loray, I would never. Not her. I wouldn’t take that from her.

Didn't you already take something from her? A moment of silence. Loray looks off toward the side of t lift hill. They’re almost 200 feet above the Strip. William reaches for Loray’s hand. She’s confused for a moment. When William lets go, Loray opens her palm. He’s surreptitiously handed her FOURTEEN VICODIN PILLS.
They're all there. I didn’t take a single one. I mean, yes, I took them out of her purse about four minutes after I met her. But I didn’t take them. (MORE )
I’ve thought about them nonstop since they’ve come into my possession, but I haven’t taken one. There’s a moment of relieved silence for Loray. Then:
What do you expect me to do with these? You know I prefer crack.
I don’t know. We'll give them back to her and she’1l hate me and I’1l1 have a pathetic story for my next NA meeting.
No. I like how she looks at you. She looks at you like you’re a good person and not a total jagoff.
I know. But I can’t let her think you stole it.
I don’t care. Let’s protect her from something. She’s gotta hang on to some of that sweetness. As the train crests the lift hill, Loray tosses the handf of tiny white pills over the side.
What are you doing? Loray does her best meterologist impression.
Tonight’s Clark County forecast calls for scattered flurries. William watches the pills disappear.
Merry Christmas, assholes.
Open your damn mouths! The train PLUNGES into the roller coaster’s spaghetti-lik mass of steel track.  74.
Lamb's head is hanging between her knees.
Hey. Hey. You going to be okay? They're standing on the still-busy sidewalk. Lamb downpla her nausea and discomfort.
Yes. I’m phenomenal. She stands up. We see a spot of BLOOD on the elbow of her cardigan.
You're bleeding.
(downplaying) I think I bumped my elbow going around one of those turns. William pulls up the sleeve of the cardigan. Lamb recoils from this violation of privacy.
Stop it. The elbow of Lamb’s compression garment is SOAKED in bloo Loray winces and looks away.
You're hurt.
It’s my skin graft. William is trying to stay calm.
Can they re-graft it? Lamb pulls away from him angrily.
Yeah, at a special clinic in Minnesota for human-jerky. I TOLD you I was a mess. I told you. Nobody ever believes me.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy)
You're not a mess. It’s not a big deal. You just need to take it easy. Chill at the hotel.
Chill? I’m tired of “taking it easy.” I’ve been taking it easy for two years now and I feel like I’m rotting alive.
From a scientific standpoint, we’re all rotting alive.
My gosh, I never thought about it that way. You’re so wise. On Loray: OWNED.
I think you’ve had enough fun for the night. We need to patch you up. Lamb is clutching her bleeding elbow.

Enough fun my skinless ass! It’s easy for you to say “enough” and to “take it easy”, because you already got to do everything you wanted. You already got to screw up and disappoint your whole family. On William: sadly, this is true.
You've got those lines on your face and that silver in your hair because you lived. Now it’s my turn.
I'm a dirtbag. You don’t want to be like me.
(through tears) Yes I do.  76.
You're lucky you had a nice life. I know you resent all the Jesus stuff and not being allowed to wear shorts and the fact that they made you practice the recorder every day.
The flute.
But there are worse things than being protected. Having someone care where you go and what happens to you. We can see that Loray has wished for this very thing. Wil glances at her protectively.

People in your family are probably looking for you right now. Nobody's looked for me in years. The last time someone Googled me, there was no Google. They had to Alta Vista that shit. Lamb looks up at Loray, still holding her elbow.

Also, I’m not the one bleeding on the street right now. You've lived, all right? All right, plane crash? You lived, you died, and now you’re living again. You’re a lot harder than most of these clowns. She gestures to the LATE NIGHT REVELERS on the street.
Let’s get you to the hospital.
Don’t bother. They’1l just wrap it in some gauze and parade me around in front of the med students. I hate when people treat me like I’m some kind of curiosity. Loray glances at William. Guilty.  77.
I’m just going to go back to my hotel.
You're not going alone.
Why not? I took a taxi from the airport. I know what I’m doing.
Let William take you back. William looks at Loray, surprised. Loray nods.
He’s the best guy when you need taking care of. Once I got food poisoning at work and he guarded the door to the women’s bathroom for six hours. William smiles at this awful-yet-touching memory.
He’s not perfect. I’1l tell you no lies. But he’1ll get you home in one piece. Or whatever pieces you've got left. Lamb giggles through the pain.
You can trust him. With that, she extends her blessing. William’s gratitude evident. Loray’s RESPECT means a lot to him. Lamb considers it.
William flags a CAB. Loray waits with Lamb on the sidewal taxi appears and pulls up to the curb. William gives Loray a friendly hug and a peck.
(to Loray) Good night, sweetie.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 78.
See you in the pit. William gestures for Lamb to enter the cab. She hesitates
You go ahead. I want to say goodbye to Loray. William shrugs and hops in, leaving Loray and Lamb on the sidewalk.
It was truly a pleasure to meet you. I know our time together was short, but I valued it.
It was something meeting you, too. (then) Hey, look, I’m sorry I teased you about all that sex stuff. I could tell it upset you. It was pretty insensitive of me.
Oh, sheesh, it’s fine. It’s not like I’m a virgin.
Uh, what? Lamb is shockingly casual.

I’ve had sex. Of course. (explaining) I had sexual relations with Pastor Rick, or just “Rick” as he asked me to call him during that fateful youth retreat. I’d been attracted to him for a while and I succumbed to baser urges. Looking back, I can see that it was an abuse of power on his part, but what’s done is done... Loray’s like what the fuck?
Don’t tell me you’re surprised. You think fundamentalist Christians don’t have sex? (MORE )
Ha, everyone has sex. It’s the one thing they haven’t figured out how to control.
I just thought...

Even the church leaders do it. Sometimes they get caught with other men, even! Don’t you read the news? She hops into the cab, shrugging cheerfully despite her injury. Loray prevents her from shutting the car door.
Wait. What’s going to happen to you?
You don’t care.
Let’s pretend I do.
I don’t know.
Well, I know you think Las Vegas was kind of a bust. But this is all make-believe. It’s fake, like Goddess. Lamb smiles.
If you still want to be a regular American, like you said? Lamb nods.
I think you need to go see America. Lamb takes in this advice. Then:
Hey, you know how you said no one ever came looking for you? That nobody cares where you are?  80.
Yeah?

Well, I followed you into the bathroom. And then I followed you downtown and, well, I gotta say... more people should come looking for you. They’d find some amazing things. Lamb reaches, painfully, to shut the CAB DOOR. Loray intercepts, closing it gently and waving goodbye to her “Disney princess.”

William and Lamb enter the lobby. William is holding Lamb injured elbow. They look cozy. Yet another group of adorable young COLLEGE GIRLS walks b They're not “bad girls” ; they’re just having the time of their life. They carry drinks and laugh. Lamb watches the enviously. This is the normal life she dreams of. Three of them cluster together for a photo while one hold her camera phone.
Say it with me, guys...1-2-3... (everyone together) Phenom-enal! Lamb turns to William suddenly.
Where do you think they’re going? William is dismissive. Derisive, even.
I don’t know. There’s a nightclub at this hotel that all the “Trixies” and “Chads” seem to love. They're probably going there.
I want to go to the club.
I don’t think that’s one of the recommended steps in wound care.  81.
Just for a minute. Just for one minute so I can see.
It’s not you. It’s loud and crowded and it’s full of disgusting aggressive people who will try to put their...private parts...against your...rear end.
You don’t have to mince words around me, William. You can say butt. Look, I said “butt” and hell didn’t swallow me up. A crying BRIDE stomps past, holding up her soiled hem.
You sure about that?
Let's go.
Okay.
(surprised) Okay? Okay! She clutches her elbow in pain, grinning.
A long line of CLUBGOERS snakes out of a huge, high-conce Vegas hotel nightclub. William moves easily to the front of the line, exchanges pleasantries with the DOOR GUY, and ushers Lamb in.

The interior of the club is a dark labyrinth. There are beautiful half-naked GIRLS dancing everywhere in Eden-the fig leaf ensembles. The music is bone-jarringly loud. Lamb keeps one hand on William’s shoulder as he cuts thro the crowd. She’s never seen this many people crammed into place.  82. They finally emerge at the CENTER OF THE CLUB. It’s the t of night when drunk and drugged people completely lose th minds. It’s so loud that William can’t speak to Lamb, and vice versa. He simply gestures as if to say, “Here we are Lamb's expression is hard to read. Her face is solemn. Th are CLUB KIDS going wild all around them. Lamb is surroun by mayhem and indecency. William is concerned. Has he gon too far? A TINSEL CANNON goes off, spewing silver tinsel into the It pours down on the cheering crowd. Lamb can’t move, but she smiles. She starts laughing. It’ the happiest William has seen her.

Lamb and William are standing in the corner of an OPEN ELEVATOR, about to ride up to her floor. Lamb’s hair is f of tinsel. Suddenly, two of the FRAT GUYS we saw when Lamb first arr run to make the elevator. One shoves his hand between the closing doors; they both hop in. Their eyes are bloodshot they're clearly messed up on some kind of disco biscuits.
Hi, guys! The two GUYS freeze, horrified.
(under his breath) Oh shit, it’s the narc. It’s the narc, man!
No, silly, narcs report to me. I’m a fed, remember? The guys back away.
This is my partner, Officer Cha. William plays along flawlessly.
Good evening, boys. Or should I say, good morning! My, you seem wide awake at such a wee hour.  83.
(twitching) We drank a lot of coffee. Energy drinks.
Energy drinks.
Your pupils are unusually large. I better get my eye flashlight. The frat guys are wildly stabbing the “open door” button.
Very strange indeed, Officer Krupke. Say, do you mind if I ask where you purchased those drinks?
We have to go. The two guys dash off the elevator. William looks at Lamb amused.
How long have you been here?
Only a few hours, I swear. INT. HOTEL ROOM - 3:00 A.M. Lamb and William enter Lamb’s suite. William is surprised its size.
This is some room. Did they comp you or something?
I had a coupon. This seems an unlikely explanation, but William lets it g

I was planning to stay here for a while anyway. William looks around the immaculate suite. He sees Lamb's clothing. Her Obama book. Her flute in its case. Then he Lamb's DISHES sitting in a neat stack.  84.
What’s with the dishes? Lamb sighs.

I brought my own dishes from home. I don’t know why people find this so strange! (exasperated) I had to let go of a lot of prejudices and fears to come to Las Vegas, so I don’t know why it’s such a big deal that I’d want to have my own tableware. I should have something familiar. Hotels are notoriously dirty.
It’s fine. I was just wondering. You know, hotel comforters are supposed to be the worst. Lamb eyes the patterned BEDSPREAD warily.
Really?
Yeah, they don’t wash them and they’re allegedly covered in se... (correcting himself) Cigar...ette ash.
Should I take it off?
Sure. Lamb pulls the comforter off the bed and onto the floor. There’s something awkward about discussing the bed.
You didn’t have to come all the way to my room. I could have found my way up from the lobby.
I see that you can take care of yourself. You’d already used some kind of mind trick on those bros in the elevator.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 85.
Well, that’s a bit like hypnotizing chickens. (off his blank look) Easy. William sits down on the DESK CHAIR.
So when you said you'd be staying here for a while, how long did you mean?
I don’t know. I just don’t want to go back to Billings.
There are other places on the good- times continuum between Billings and the Vegas Strip.
I'm figuring that out.
Hm. You know, I think you'd love Chicago.
Where are you from?
Chicago. Lamb smiles.
Since I’m never going to see you again, you should know-- you have a right to know-- that I’m the one who stole your Vicodin. I fished them right out of your bag.
Abhh... We think she’s going to protest.
.--bviously.
How did you know that?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 86.
I left my purse with you and you're a recovering drug addict. My mom always says that when people tell you who they are, you should listen. William nods: fair enough.

I mean, I understand. I’m not without my vices. I’m totally addicted to-- well, you know those vanilla sandwich cookies, with the creme filling? I love them. If you had a big bag of those cookies, boy, when you weren’t looking? I'd eat a couple. Maybe I’d eat 10. My flesh is weak. She’s anything but weak, and William knows that.
I doubt that.
No, I’1l admit it. I love vanilla sandwich cookies. (quietly, almost whispering) And also Vicodin.

What? Lamb whispers again, this time closer to him. He nods. WILLIAM (CONT’D) I think you can get the situation under control. The cookies, I mean. Lamb looks worried and self-conscious. Obviously, he’s no talking about the cookies.
I don’t know.
If you need help, there are lots of counselors that specialize in creme- filled desserts. No big whoop. But personally? I think there probably isn’t anything you can’t do.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 87.
William, I mean no offense. But are you trying to get into my surgical support hose?
No. This is not to say I wouldn't. I would. Lamb blushes.
I would! I love support hose. I would peel ‘em right off. Throw them around my head like a lasso. Lamb bursts out laughing despite being totally scandalize
I think I should go. I understand if you don’t want to exchange email or whatever. Or regular addresses. You do live on a street, right?
Rural Route 13. And don’t go.
(surprised) What?
Don't go.
I lied to you. I’m a liar and an addict Just another Vegas lost cause. Why do you keep trusting me?
It’s a very potent act to put your faith in someone who’s lost their faith in themselves.
Yeah, I guess it is. Lamb seems to have an epiphany.
Will you help me with something that might seem weird?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 88.
What have we been doing all night? INT. HOTEL ROOM - 3:30 A.M. Lamb sits on her bed and picks up the ROOM PHONE. We can’ see who she’s calling. William lingers supportively.
